hints.content: Start by understanding how to represent the books using the given array format. Each book has a thickness and a height, which will be crucial for determining how they fit on the shelves.
Consider how you will keep track of the current width of the shelf as you add books. You will need to sum the thickness of the books you are currently placing on the shelf.

Think about the condition for moving to a new shelf. When the current shelf's width plus the thickness of the next book exceeds the shelfWidth, you should finalize the current shelf and start a new one.
As you add books to a shelf, keep track of the maximum height of the books on that shelf. This height will contribute to the total height of the bookcase.
You may want to use a loop to iterate through the books and a variable to hold the current width and maximum height of the shelf. This will help you manage the state as you process each book.
Consider edge cases, such as when a single book is wider than the shelfWidth. In such cases, you will need to handle that book separately, as it cannot be placed on any shelf.
Remember that the order of books must be preserved. You cannot skip books or rearrange them; they must be placed on the shelves in the order they appear in the input array.
Think about how to calculate the total height of the bookcase after all books have been placed. This will be the sum of the heights of all the shelves you have created.
You might find it helpful to create a variable to accumulate the total height of the bookcase as you finalize each shelf. This will make it easier to return the final result.

To bring it all together, you will need to implement a loop that iterates through the books, checks the width condition, updates the current shelf height, and resets for new shelves as needed. Consider how you will return the total height after processing all books.

questionNotes: Books must be placed in the order given.
Return the minimum possible height of the total bookshelf.
